abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Bauxite Industry Technical Assistance
            Project in Guyana. The major goals of the revised project
            were to: (i) stabilize and restructure Linmine's (the
            most important Guyanese bauxite operation) finances; (ii)
            rehabilitate its operational capacity; and (iii) lay the
            basis to privatize it, in order to recover the
            company's sales potential. IDA performance was
            generally good. The Borrower's apparent lack of
            aggressiveness with respect to project supervision or in the
            pursuit of an agreed privatization strategy, especially in
            the period following the 1992 elections, added to the delays
            in execution of the revised project. The major lessons
            learned from the project were: (a) International Development
            Association (IDA) and its borrowers need to be exceedingly
            thorough in assessing whether the instruments and experience
            available to IDA match the client's needs and are
            adequate to manage the risks which may be encountered during
            project implementation; (b) the use of a project with
            intricately-woven conditionalities is not sufficiently
            flexible for carrying out time-sensitive undertakings, as
            required in the case of Linmine; (c) privatization projects
            should not aim to rehabilitate, given that the investment
            strategy of the potential investor is unknown and the
            rehabilitation might tend to harden the negotiating stance
            of the government; (d) the role of IDA and other public
            financial institutions in such pragmatic deals remains an
            open question; (e) IDA procurement guidelines may be too
            complex and not appropriate to the process of selecting a
            joint venture partner in delicate restructuring and
            privatization processes; and (f) financial restructuring
            should not try to involuntarily reschedule payments to
            important suppliers of goods and services to an operating
            company, as they are essential to its continued operation.
